newsitem.title: SOUTH KOREA: Seoul stocks close down led by Jinro units, banks.
newsitem.headline: Seoul stocks close down led by Jinro units, banks.

text.p: South Korean stocks closed lower on Thursday after trading in positive territory for most of the day as banks lost ground on profit-taking, brokers said.
The composite index closed at 690.80, down 2.25 points. It was off an intraday high of 697.43.
Affiliates of the troubled Jinro Group fell as investors continued to be concerned about the group's future.
Samsung Electronics shares were unmoved by the news that Standard & Poor's had cut Samsung's long-term rating outlook.
New Star Trading fell after Savoy Hotel offered a tender to buy 25.3 percent of New Star in a takeover bid.

"Selling increased once the index approached the 700-point resistance level," said analyst Koh Kyung-bae of Hyundai Securities. "Trading was also hit by rumours that several companies besides Jinro were also in financial trouble."
Samsung Electronics closed flat at 59,600 after rising to 60,500. Standard & Poor's Corp said on Thursday it had cut Samsung's rating outlook to negative from stable.
Jinro Ltd lost 660 won to its daily limit of 7,690. Jinro Industries fell 360 won to its limit of 4,170 and Jinro General Foods by 290 won to 3,620.
The troubled Jinro Group has said it would sell off some of its property and affiliates to raise cash to pay back its debt, estimated at 3.2 trillion won.
New Star Trading fell 4,900 won to its limit of 57,200. Savoy on Thursday offered to buy 120,785 shares of New Star for 62,500 won per share in a bid to take over New Star.
If successful, Savoy's stake in the garment maker would rise to 50 percent, surpassing the current largest single stake of 29.26 percent held by New Star's president and his family.
